args: ...Big words from you, pal. Can't believe \nyou thought a joke like that was worth it.
Perish the thought; I am entirely serious.
That wasn't funny as a joke, and it REALLY\nisn't funny as a serious statement!
Looks like you two are tight as ever.\nWhat's going on this time?
Oh, my friend here is just spewing his\nusual supply of steaming hot nonsense.
He's lording something over me about how\nthere's no unsolvable mystery in the world.\nOnly natural that I'd be upset, right?
I'm not lording anything over anyone.\nI am merely stating the truth.
And there we go. You know, it would be\nreally refreshing if you'd just admit that\nthis is all your own overconfidence.
And yet it is not; I'm not saying that I can\nsimply solve every mystery straight away.

However, provided it comes after
substantive investigation, research, and
deduction, there exists no such thing as an
unsolvable problem. Not to me, at least.

If you wish to prove the efficacy of your
statement, you merely need bring before
me a mystery of sufficient cleverness.
...As opposed to the usual slop you find.
Hmm... Actually, I bet I DO know\na mystery you can't solve!

You're a quiet, unsociable guy with a
cement brick where your heart should be.
There's no way you'll ever figure out
what love is supposed to be like.

Ha! I was wondering what drivel might
spill forth from your slack-jawed mouth.
The thing called love is merely a state of
mind formed under specific conditions.
I do plenty of research into human\nstates of mind. In fact, you might say\nit is my field of expertise.
You can say that after you've made\nsomeone actually FALL in love with you.\nUnless you're all talk, that is.
A cheap provocation at best.\nBut I shall play along.
Er, is this really a good idea?
Uh oh. You look very flustered.
Did you not get a letter from Heinwald?

Sure, I GOT it—but there's no way I was
going to read the scribblings of that
lunatic. I threw it on the bed and
forgot all about it.
I'm sorry, what?! Run that by me again?\n...Slowly. As if I am the village idiot.
It's an invitation. To a wedding.
I was just as surprised as you are—\nwhich is too bad, because I was hoping\nyou had a better idea of what's going on.

No, this is...the first I've heard about it.
However, I have a VERY bad feeling
about the whole affair. We should find
him and ask him about it directly.
So this is Heinwald's home, eh?\nIt's quite the handsome estate.
Did you not know? Heinwald is one of\nAlberia's landed nobles.
Yes, he's a nobleman. Aren't you a prince?\nShouldn't you know these things?
Yeah, I have...a lot on my plate.
Well, I guess I can't blame you;\nit's not like he looks the part.
Hello, all. You have arrived early.\nWe're not yet at the appointed day.
Just shut up for a second, Heinwald.\nNo, wait. Talk. But ONLY talk about\nthis whole ＂I'm getting married＂ thing!
If I am not mistaken—and I am not—you\nare the one who led me to this, Curran.
Heinwald, you were supposed to try and\nfind out about love—I didn't think you'd\nactually go and get MARRIED!
So long as I am going to approach a\nwoman, I will take responsibility until\nthe very end of the endeavor.
I can't decide if that's honorable or crazy.
Look, never mind. Just tell me how you\nmanaged to trick a woman into marrying\nyou in such a short period of time.

I used no special tricks in particular.
I simply told a woman I am acquainted
with that as the lord of a noble house,
I am possessed of certain financial means.
Tsk. You make it sound so disreputable.\nThe woman had something she sought,\nand I was able to fulfill those conditions.
He's right! You haven't figured out\nlove at all!
＂Love＂ is merely the workings of a\nhuman heart in search of happiness.
Said happiness takes many forms—\nchief among those being financial stability.

Of course, finances are not everything,
but it would be the height of tactlessness
to deny another person their standard
of happiness by imposing one's own.
Don't lecture me on tactless, pal!\nYou dress like a blind undertaker!
Who exactly IS the woman you're\nengaged to marry, Heinwald?
I cannot. She has not been seen\nsince yesterday morning.
If I had to guess, I'd say she thought\nabout the union and was reluctant\nto consent to its consummation.
I suppose you could say that. ...Which is\ncurious, as I'd thought her to be rather\nexcited about the whole affair.
She probably realized she'd bitten off\nmore than she could chew.
Once she learned her husband was a\ntotal eccentric, she beat feet outta here.
Eccentric? How dare you, sir.\nI am both sensible and diligent.
Seems like the only thing your brain\ncan't do is accurately evaluate itself.
Please tell me you didn't show her\nthat weird collection of yours.
Do I even want to know about this?
It's a creepy collection of weird animals\nlike mutant mice with wings, lizards fused\nwith frogs... You know. Creep-o stuff.

The mysteries of life are not creepy—they
are wonderful puzzles of the natural world!
Only a fool could gaze upon them and
not feel their heart stir in their breast!
...And I'm sure she heard this exact\nsame speech.
Heh. Well, I suppose I can see how\nthat might have changed her mind.
And then he has the gall to lecture\nme about love. Ha!
I still don't see how I did anything\nwrong in this situation.
And yet, I WILL acknowledge that there\nis an element of love which remains...\nunknown to me.
Still, I suppose I was a little careless, too.\nIt never occurred to me how far you'd\ntake this challenge once I made it.

I'm just praying that you don't say
something like ＂Oh, I must find more test
cases to re-verify my hypotheses＂ or...
Wait. You're NOT doing that, right?

I must hurry and find another bride.
...No, better! I shall mount a giant sign
in the village square advertising my
intent to all who stroll past!
